attributes.title: What really causes SME performance heterogeneity in times of crisis?
attributes.description: National Covid-19 Measures as a Natural Experiment – A pre-registration
attributes.registration_supplement: Pre-Registration in Social Psychology (van 't Veer & Giner-Sorolla, 2016): Pre-Registration

datacompletion.value: Yes, data collection is underway or complete

additionalComments.value: This project predicts the future, so the outcome variables have not yet occurred at the moment of this registration. The intervention is still underway and subject to change by the government. So, data collection has begun but only for the independent variables.

dataCollectionDates.value: Jan 1 2016. September 1 2021 (or whichever date 2020 profit data are available).

question2a.value:
See appendix B for details.
1. Before vs. after. Takes the values 0 or 1 (after). Within-firm.
2. Unaffected vs. affected. Takes the values 0 or 1 (affected). Between-firm (in fact, it varies at the industry level).
3. Ambidexterity. A multiplication of exploitation and exploration scales. Scaled to take values between 1 and 5. Between-firm.
4. Causation. 7-item 5-point scale. Between-firm. Not mutually exclusive with effectuation.
5. Effectuation. 17-item 5-point scale. Between-firm. Not mutually exclusive with causation.
6. Entrepreneurial self-efficacy. 22-item, 5-point scale. Between-firm. Different dimensions may have different effects (especially planning vs. marshaling).
7. Ambiguity intolerance. 22-item 5-point scale. Between-firm. Highly correlated with uncertainty intolerance.
8. Uncertainty intolerance. 8-item 5-point scale. Between-firm. Highly correlated with ambiguity intolerance.
9. Psychological agility. 30-item 7-point scale. Between-firm.

question2b.value:
Profitability refers to logged profit (code 9901 in Belgium; a kind of earnings before interest and taxes). Before the Covid-19 intervention, this refers to the profit over 2019; after the intervention, this refers to the profit over 2020. 
Regarding survival, we create a dummy that equals 0 if a firm did not survive the crisis, and 1 if the SME is still in operation at the end of 2020.

question3b.value:
Firm size. Classes 1-6 based on number of employees. Covariate.
We will investigate the difference of means of variables between unaffected and affected firms. If the intervention is not randomly assigned with respect to those variables, that may indicate self-selection bias or contingency effects. Thus, we may include the average of that variable in each cell (before vs. after*unaffected vs. affected) as a covariate to control for those.

question10b.value:
As we explain in detail in van Witteloostuijn et al. (2020), we collected rich, multi-level and multi-source data of Flemish SMEs in the context of a large project co-financed by the Flemish government (i.e., the government of Flanders, which is the Dutch-speaking part of Belgium) as of 2016, and still ongoing. This project offers an evidence-based coaching service to SMEs. At the time of writing this pre-registration, about 600 SMEs had participated in the project. As part of the coaching service, we gathered comprehensive data regarding the participating SMEs, administering two questionnaires and a series of Brief Implicit Association Tests (BIATs). In the context of the current study, key is our collaboration with Graydon in this project. Graydon is a data service provider, collecting and processing information regarding enterprises on an, essentially, real-time basis. Through this collaboration, we cannot only append important demographic and financial information to our data (e.g., SME industry and profitability), but also the very status of each and every SME in our database – i.e., whether the SME is still operational or is out of business. 
The intervention is natural, so its randomization is controlled by the government. The intervention is not completely randomly assigned. The government intervenes strategically in industries that involve physical proximity of people. However, it seems implausible for physical proximity of people to be a relevant circumstance as a contingency for the effect of those independent variables on SME performance, and therefore not independent of self-selection into our independent variables.

question4b.value: Our sample consists of 532 Flemish SMEs for which we have completed data entry at this point. The final sample used in the analysis may become somewhat greater or smaller depending on missing values and ongoing data entry.

question5b.value:
Strategy and entrepreneur attributes are already collected during the years before the intervention.
Our source of performance data is Graydon.

question6b.value: The sample is large and unique for the standards in the field of entrepreneurship. The before and after variable means we will observe each firm twice, such that the final n=1064. Even with triple interactions, there should be more than 100 observations per cell.

question7b.value: Analyses will be done as soon as 2020 profit is available, on the data we have collected up to that point.

question8b.value:
Firms that miss an independent variable will be included in analyses for independent variables which they do not miss.
Firms that do not survive the crisis cannot be included in the profitability analysis, but will be included in the survival analysis.

question6c.value: We evaluate predictions based on practical relevance of the effect size rather than statistical significance. Therefore, corrections for multiple tests are not needed.

question7c.value:
If a firm misses an independent variable, it will still be included for analyses on other independent variables.
If a firm does not survive throughout 2020, it will not be incorporated in the profitability analyses.

question8c.value: The scales included in the planned analyses are already tested to have sufficient reliability.

question9c.value:
Profit will be logged (specifically, inverse hyperbolic sine as profit can be negative).
Ambidexterity will be a multiplication of the exploitation and exploration scales, scaled back to the 1-5 range.

extra.selectedFileName: What really causes SME performance heterogeneity in times of crisis National Covid-19 Measures as a Natural Experiment – A pre-registration.docx

question1a.value:
Prediction 1 (Ambidexterity): Ambidexterity decreases performance in crises. Specifically, ambidexterity reduces an SME’s (a) profitability and (b) likelihood of survival in the face of Covid-19 demand-reducing or nullifying measures.

Prediction 2 (Causation): Causation decreases performance in crises. Specifically, causation reduces an SME’s (a) profitability and (b) likelihood of survival in the face of Covid-19 demand-reducing or nullifying measures.

Prediction 3 (Effectuation): Effectuation increases performance in crises. Specifically, effectuation increases an SME’s (a) profitability and (b) likelihood of survival in the face of Covid-19 demand-reducing or nullifying measures.

Prediction 4 (Entrepreneurial self-efficacy): Entrepreneurial self-efficacy increases performance during crises. Specifically, entrepreneurial self-efficacy increases an SME’s (a) profitability and (b) likelihood of survival in the face of Covid-19 demand-reducing or nullifying measures.

Prediction 5 (Intolerance): (i) Ambiguity intolerance and (ii) uncertainty intolerance decrease performance in crises. Specifically, (i) ambiguity intolerance and (ii) uncertainty intolerance decrease an SME’s (a) profitability and (b) likelihood of survival in the face of Covid-16 demand-reducing or nullifying measures.

Prediction 6 (Psychological agility): Psychological agility increases performance in crises. Specifically, psychological agility increases an SME’s (a) profitability and (b) likelihood of survival in the face of Covid-19 demand-reducing or nullifying measures.

question2a.value: We use a dif-in-dif approach, so statistically all predictions are triple interactions with the dummy variable 'before vs. after' and 'unaffected vs. affected'. In the unaffected group, performance should decrease from before to after the intervention, as the crisis has indirect effects. In the affected group, performance should more strongly decrease from before to after the intervention as their demand is reduced or even nullified. Predictions that a strategy increases (decreases) performance in crises imply that, affected firms with that strategy have weaker (stronger) decrease from before to after the invention than those without that strategy. The predictions do not imply that the performance gap between before and after grows or shrinks on average. Nor do they imply performance gaps between treated and control groups. Nor do they imply that a strategy is more effective before or after the intervention, or more effective for the treated or control group. The lack of those implication is due to the contingent and biased relationship between entrepreneur attributes/strategy and performance making it difficult to predict the performance of the unaffected group; i.e., the reason for our natural experiment. Figure 1 visualizes how these considerations play out, using prediction 1 as an example.

question3a.value: The treatment is natural rather than manipulated. In other words, we do not control the government's Covid-19 measures.

data.name: Figure 1 Visualization of a result consistent with prediction 1.png

extra.selectedFileName: Figure 1 Visualization of a result consistent with prediction 1.png

question5a.value:
A large part of the Covid-19 national crisis management intervention reduces or nullifies demand. In extreme cases, demand is restricted to zero for all firms in specific industries. So, while many strategies are theorized to affect firm performance via impacting demand, that logic is implausible for our predictions. Furthermore, the firms we consider are SMEs, most of them with fewer than 50 employees, whereas much traditional strategy theorizing applies to large(r) enterprises. Below, we focus on one strategic concept that is, strictly speaking, universal in nature, and applies to all enterprises irrespective of size: ambidexterity. The other pair of strategies originates in the entrepreneurship literature, and primarily relates to an SME’s mode of strategizing: causation and effectuation. Because of the theoretical connection between ambidexterity, on the one hand, and causation and effectuation, on the other hand (Sarasvathy, 2001), it will be interesting to contrast their effects in times of crisis.

Next, we move to our selection of three attributes of the individual entrepreneur running the SME. The debate regarding the impact of attributes of the individual entrepreneur, vis-à-vis that of the environment and the firm, is ongoing by now for decades, if not centuries (e.g., Shapero, 1975). Such individual attributes range from demographic characteristics to personality traits (Wijbenga & van Witteloostuijn, 2007). From the long list of general attributes that has been studied in the SME performance literature, we include one that has, since long, been identified as critical for entrepreneurship: risk-taking. Additionally, we introduce an attribute that is novel to the entrepreneurship literature, but arguably essential in hard times: psychological agility. Finally, we add an attribute that is currently prominent in the entrepreneurship literature, but whose effect in times of crises is still unknown: entrepreneurial self-efficacy.

question6a.value: Our setting is outside of the scope of most theories, so the connection between theory and prediction is too weak for well-behaved horse races.

question1c.value:
Profit. Logged profit in euros
After. Indicator variable.
Affected. Indicator variable.
Ambidexterity. (see Appendix B)
Firm size. 6 classes by number of employees.

question2c.value: We consider two approaches in our predictive leg. For logged profitability, the outcome variable should be a normally distributed continuous variable, so an OLS model can estimate coefficients appropriately. The predictions are about direct effects without considering covariates or the other attributes and strategies. Furthermore, the difference-in-difference procedure should reduce the need for covariates. Still, firm size (a classification running from 1 to 6 regarding the number of employees) may be useful to include as a covariate.

question3c.value:
Profit is the DV.
Ambidexterity is the main IV. After and unaffected are moderators in a triple interaction with ambidexterity.
Firm size is a covariate.

question4c.value: Firm size should correlate with profit and survival and strategy. Moreover, largers firms may be better able to respond to the Covid-19 measures, while smaller firms simply have to close. Alternatively, smaller firms may not close because there are not a large enough number of people in close proximity. In any case, firm size may not be independent from the intervention.

question5c.value: We test predictions with respect to the alternative of no correlation. We evaluate the results based on practical relevance of effect size rather than statistical significance.

question1c.value:
Survival. Indicator variable =1 if firm survived until end of 2020.
After. Indicator variable.

Ambidexterity. (see Appendix B)

question2c.value: For survival, the outcome variable is a 0-1 dummy. Thus, we use logit models with specification similar to the OLS models. As an additional analysis, we contrast our results excluding bias and in special circumstances with the results of models estimating the same effects on performance data gathered before the intervention (i.e., a normal correlational study) (including bias and in normal circumstances).

attributes.title: Organ Donation
attributes.description:
Policy makers seek to find solutions to increase the number of organ donations worldwide. In 
some countries (e.g., the Netherlands), governments are going to introduce an opt-out system (everybody is a 
donor unless he or she opts out) to increase donations. Evidence shows that an opt-out organ donation default 
increases the number of cadaveric donations while the number of living donations decreases. Previous research 
shows that organ donation under an opt-out default is seen as mundane while under the opt-in default is 
perceived as an extremely altruistic act. Furthermore, media appeals highlight the shortage of organs, which 
reinforces the concept that people, in general, do not cooperate and free-ride by not registering to donate. In 
contrast, the virtues of the opt-out default increasing the number of organs available are highlighted as its major 
benefit. Thus, a supply-demand effect may operate to account for the reduction in living donations, especially to 
strangers, under an opt-out default. That is, people perceive more organs are available under the opt-out default 
and as a result feel less inclined to donate as a living donor especially to a stranger. In contrast under an opt-in 
default, where free-riding is predominant, any donation is seen as an extreme act and conditional cooperation 
would suggest that people will be more like to donate a living organ if they perceive that other also donate under 
opt-in.  
But is it really the organ donation policy that leads to more or less people being willing to make living 
donations? Or is it just a matter of whether people believe that there are enough donors or not?

q1.value: Willingness to living organ donation and organ donation registration. A matter of the default system?

q2.value: Eva-Maria Merz, Eamonn Ferguson, Elisabeth Huis in 't Veld, Jonathan Tan, Sinika Studte, Michel Clement, Pascal Güntürkün

q3.value: Worldwide, a constant shortage of donor organs for transplantation challenges patient care. Policy makers seek to find solutions to increase the number of organ donations. In some countries (e.g., England, the Netherlands), governments are going to introduce an opt-out system (everybody is a donor unless he or she opts out) with the idea to increase available donor organs. Evidence shows indeed that an opt-out organ donation default increases the number of posthumous donations while the number of living donations decreases (see Shepherd, O’Carroll &Ferguson 2014; Fernandez, Howard and Krose, 2013). Furthermore, Fernandez et al. (2012) show that this effect is specific to living donations to a stranger. Organ donation under an opt-out default is seen as a mundane (similar to letting someone go ahead of you in a queue) while under the opt-in default is perceived as an extremely altruistic act (similar to giving away 50% wealth to charity after death)(Davidai, Gilovich and Ross (2012)). Furthermore, media appeals highlight the shortage of organs, which reinforces the concept that people, in general, do not cooperate and free-ride by not registering to donate (Bail, 2016). In contrast, the virtues of the opt-out default increasing the number of organs available are highlighted as its major benefit. Thus, a supply-demand effect may operate to account for the reduction in living donations, especially to strangers, under an opt-out default. People might perceive more organs are available under the opt-out default and as a result feel less inclined to donate as a living donor, especially to a stranger. In contrast under an opt-in default, where free-riding is predominant, any donation is seen as an extreme act and conditional cooperation would suggest that people will be more likely to donate a living organ if they perceive that others also donate under opt-in. But is it really the organ donation policy that leads to more or less people being willing to make living donations? Or is it just a matter of whether people believe that there are enough donors or not?

q4.value:
From previous work in this area (Davidai et al., 2012; Shepherd et al., 2014) we make the following testable predictions.
Living donation intentions are lower under an opt-out than under an opt-in consent system, due to perceived higher availability of organs. This association will be stronger under the hypothetical condition of 85% registration rate compared to 15%. We also predict that the correlation between the perceived availability of deceased organs and willingness to be a living donor will be negative under an opt-out system and that this negative association will be stronger then the association observed between these variables under an opt-in system. Living donation attitudes, beliefs and intentions vary as a function of the consent system such that living donation under opt-in system is perceived as extreme heroic deed, while under opt-out more as a mundane act. 
In summary, we hypothesize that under and opt-out policy compared to an opt-in system:
1.	People will be less willing to be a living donor 
2.	People will report less positive attitudes, norms and beliefs towards living donation

q5.value: Observational Study - Data is collected from study subjects that are not randomly assigned to a treatment. This includes surveys, “natural experiments,” and regression discontinuity designs.

value: Personnel who interact directly with the study subjects (either human or non-human subjects) will not be aware of the assigned treatments. (Commonly known as “double blind”)

question.value:
We will randomly allocate 200 participants per country to an opt-in or an opt-out condition (see below) and to a hypothetical proportion of registered posthumous donors of 85% or 15%. See figure 1 for conditions as offered to the participants. In addition, 200 respondents will be allocated to the control group with the ‘true’ situation in the respective country, regarding the consent system and the proportion of registered/not-deregistered donors In total, we aim to include 1,000 respondents per country. 

	                                       Opt-in	                 Opt-out	           'true’ situation
15% registration rate	200 participants	200 participants	
85% registration rate	200 participants	200 participants	
‘true’ situation			                                                        200 participants
Fig. 1 Treatment and control conditions

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value: Participants will be approached by a commercial panel in the respective countries. The panel provider „respondi“ has been a long term panel expert since 2005 and operates its own access panels in ten European countries. The participants in our panel are between 18 and 70 years of age and are representative of the population in terms of age and gender. The test persons are paid with so-called mingle points, which can be redeemed for cash or shopping vouchers. For 20 minutes of questioning, the participants receive mingle points worth one euro.

q13.value: We will randomly allocate 200 participants per country to an opt-in or an opt-out condition (see below) and to a hypothetical proportion of registered posthumous donors of 85% or 15%. See figure 1 for conditions as offered to the participants. In addition, 200 respondents will be allocated to the control group with the ‘true’ situation in the respective country, regarding the consent system and the proportion of registered/not-deregistered donors In total, we aim to include 1,000 respondents per country.

question.value:
Our key dependent variable is (1) willingness to be a living organ donor. We ask participants about their willingness to donate a kidney, a lobe of their liver to a stranger, relative or friends on a 7-point Likert scale ranging from 1 not at all likely to 7 extremely likely. (2) Similarly, we inquire into the likelihood of registration or de-registration under a given consent system on a 7-point Likert scale ranging from 1 not at all likely to 7 extremely likely. And (3) we collect information on social norms, beliefs, and reputation building concerning organ donation as possible mediators in the association between consent-system and willingness to living organ donation and posthumous organ donation registration/de-registration. We use the belief/trust that others donate scale (Evans & Ferguson, 2014), the social norms scale (Lemmens et al., 2009) and the reputation building scale (Chell & Mortimer, 2014). Participants score propositions on a on a 7-point Likert scale ranging from 1 strongly disagree to 7 strongly agree. 
	As control variables we include altruism, reciprocity and attitudes. We use the Philanthropy Scale (Schuyt, Bekkers, & Smit, 2010) with 7 items, rated on a 5-point Likert scale ranging from 1 not at all likely to 5 extremely likely. General norms of reciprocity are measured using the General norms of reciprocity scale (Perugini et al. 2003). Self-reported altruism using the self-reported altruism scale (SRA; Rushton, Chrisjohn, & Fekken, 1981) is measured with 20 items answered on a 5-point scale ranging from 1 never to 5 very often. Personal moral norms are measured with 3 items, answered on a on a on a 7-point Likert scale ranging from 1 strongly disagree to 7 strongly agree. Furthermore, background information and demographic controls are measured: knowledge about organ donation, donation, transplantation in social network, trust in medical system, subjective health, age, gender, religious and ethnic background.  

Interaction scenario (altruism)
In addition to altruism measured with the SRA scale we offer an interaction scenario to the participants. We make participants think about a social interaction between them and a stranger. They are told to have been given €10. They can decide to give some, none or all to another person whose identity will be kept unknown and that their decision is completely anonymous. They are then asked how much money they would want to give the other person (0-10€)? €______________

Our key dependent variables are willingness to make a living kidney or liver lobe donation to a friend, stranger or relative and intention to register or de-register as posthumous donor under the different conditions. First, we will assess the main and interaction effects of the treatments on the willingness to donate and intention to (de)register using ANOVA.. Second, as both variables are measured as interval variables, we will apply linear regression models to our data for including the respective mediators. We conduct mediation analyses (i.e., ZMediation, Iacobucci 2012) and/or structural equation models to test to what extent the social norms, beliefs, and reputation building are able to explain the effects of consent system and hypothetical registration rate on willingness to make a living donation and organ donor (de)registration for posthumous donations. We test mediations only when this main effect proved to be statistically significant and control for the above mentioned co-variates, i.e. demographics and other background variables, altruism, reciprocity, attitudes.

registration_responses.q1: Willingness to living organ donation and organ donation registration. A matter of the default system?
registration_responses.q2: Eva-Maria Merz, Eamonn Ferguson, Elisabeth Huis in 't Veld, Jonathan Tan, Sinika Studte, Michel Clement, Pascal Güntürkün
registration_responses.q3: Worldwide, a constant shortage of donor organs for transplantation challenges patient care. Policy makers seek to find solutions to increase the number of organ donations. In some countries (e.g., England, the Netherlands), governments are going to introduce an opt-out system (everybody is a donor unless he or she opts out) with the idea to increase available donor organs. Evidence shows indeed that an opt-out organ donation default increases the number of posthumous donations while the number of living donations decreases (see Shepherd, O’Carroll &Ferguson 2014; Fernandez, Howard and Krose, 2013). Furthermore, Fernandez et al. (2012) show that this effect is specific to living donations to a stranger. Organ donation under an opt-out default is seen as a mundane (similar to letting someone go ahead of you in a queue) while under the opt-in default is perceived as an extremely altruistic act (similar to giving away 50% wealth to charity after death)(Davidai, Gilovich and Ross (2012)). Furthermore, media appeals highlight the shortage of organs, which reinforces the concept that people, in general, do not cooperate and free-ride by not registering to donate (Bail, 2016). In contrast, the virtues of the opt-out default increasing the number of organs available are highlighted as its major benefit. Thus, a supply-demand effect may operate to account for the reduction in living donations, especially to strangers, under an opt-out default. People might perceive more organs are available under the opt-out default and as a result feel less inclined to donate as a living donor, especially to a stranger. In contrast under an opt-in default, where free-riding is predominant, any donation is seen as an extreme act and conditional cooperation would suggest that people will be more likely to donate a living organ if they perceive that others also donate under opt-in. But is it really the organ donation policy that leads to more or less people being willing to make living donations? Or is it just a matter of whether people believe that there are enough donors or not?
registration_responses.q4:
From previous work in this area (Davidai et al., 2012; Shepherd et al., 2014) we make the following testable predictions.
Living donation intentions are lower under an opt-out than under an opt-in consent system, due to perceived higher availability of organs. This association will be stronger under the hypothetical condition of 85% registration rate compared to 15%. We also predict that the correlation between the perceived availability of deceased organs and willingness to be a living donor will be negative under an opt-out system and that this negative association will be stronger then the association observed between these variables under an opt-in system. Living donation attitudes, beliefs and intentions vary as a function of the consent system such that living donation under opt-in system is perceived as extreme heroic deed, while under opt-out more as a mundane act. 
In summary, we hypothesize that under and opt-out policy compared to an opt-in system:
1.	People will be less willing to be a living donor 
2.	People will report less positive attitudes, norms and beliefs towards living donation
registration_responses.q5: Observational Study - Data is collected from study subjects that are not randomly assigned to a treatment. This includes surveys, “natural experiments,” and regression discontinuity designs.
q6: Personnel who interact directly with the study subjects (either human or non-human subjects) will not be aware of the assigned treatments. (Commonly known as “double blind”)

attributes.title: Coronavirus Disease (COVID-19) Pandemic: Protocol of Overview of Systematic Reviews

datacompletion.value: No, data collection has not begun

registration_responses.datacompletion: No, data collection has not begun

data.value: No, no data have been collected for this study yet.

other.value: We will explore how the effect may differ when examining the individual factors of self-development (i.e., self-awareness, product knowledge, and perceived competence). We will also collect data on three exploratory variables: product evaluations (Park & John, 2012), hedonic/utilitarian attitudes toward the product (Voss, Spangenberg, & Grohman, 2003), and signaling motives (Park & John, 2010). If growth mindsets predict overall consumer self-development, we will explore whether the effect is partially explained by these exploratory mediators.

sample.value: This study aims to recruit a minimum of 172 students, and will stop data collection at 250 participants.

analyses.value:
H1: To compare growth versus fixed mindsets on the core dependent variables, an independent-means t-test will be performed on the mean score of: (a) overall consumer self-development and (b) interest.

H2: Mediation will be conducted using Model 4 of the PROCESS Macro v3.4 for SPSS and performed with 10,000 bootstrapped samples. Specifically, the mindset condition will be inserted as the independent variable, interest as the mediator, and consumer self-development as the dependent variable.

outliers.value:
Duplicate participant IDs will be identified and the second entry removed. Any participant who withdraws based on the exit consent will be removed. Data screening prior to any analyses will be conducted on the following attention/quality checks: (a) the Conscientious Responder scale, where three out of five items must be correctly answered; (b) responding “yes” to the self-report attention check item; (c) correct responses to the single item comprehension check; (d) any participant who uses a single response throughout will be removed (e.g., responding with all “1’s”); (e) no greater than a 5 minute break between the manipulation and the outcome measures, (f) screen out if participants who do not meaningfully respond to the “saying is believing” task (in other words, participants must follow the instructions); and (g) reading speed (i.e., reading more than 300 wpm; Brysbaert, 2019). 
 
Two manipulation checks are used for the mindset manipulation: (a) Check #1: The article was “difficult to understand,” “credible,” “persuasive,” rated on a 1 (strongly disagree) to 7 (strongly agree); (b) Check #2:  implicit theory questionnaire, rated on a 1 (strongly disagree) to 7 (strongly agree) point scale. Anyone who disagree with the intended direction of each article (i.e., those who, on average, disagree with the article—those who indicate the mid-point and below) will be removed before data analysis.

dependent.value:
Consumer self-development (CSD) is a three-factor construct captured across nine Likert-type items (anchored: 1 = Strongly disagree, 7 = Strongly agree). Three items are employed for each of the subscales: self-awareness, product knowledge, and perceived competence.
	
Interest (Silvia, 2005) will be captured using four 7-point Likert-type items (anchored: 1 = strongly disagree, 7 = Strongly agree).

conditions.value: Participants will be randomly assigned to one of two mindset conditions (growth vs. fixed) in a single-factor between-subjects design, where participants will read a fake scientific article that teaches readers that human characteristics are either fixed (fixed mindset) or malleable (growth). All participants complete the “saying is believing” procedure, to engage with the manipulation (Molden, Plaks, & Dweck, 2006). Participants then start an ostensibly unrelated study that in truth measures key DVs (evaluate a consumer product and capture CSD, interest, and other measured variables; see exploratory analyses).

hypothesis.value:
RQ: Does a growth (vs. fixed) mindset lead to greater consumer self-development? 

H1: Growth (vs. fixed) mindset consumers will report greater levels of expected self-development when learning about a new hedonic product.

H2: Interest will mediate the effect of mindset on self-development when consumers evaluate the hedonic product under a growth (vs. fixed) mindset.

other.value:
To study the extensive effect of our treatment we will repeat the analysis from above but binarize the dependent variable (coded 1 as long as the stated probability to go is >0% and 0 otherwise).

We also will study the intensive effect by restricting the analysis to those subjects that state that they are going to the party with a probability of >0%.

We will additionally conduct OLS regressions within each risk condition, where we will interact the main effect of the frame with risk perception, preferences, knowledge about COVID-19, gender and political orientation.

sample.value: We aim to recruit 800 subjects before exclusions.

analyses.value:
The main analysis are two ranksum tests to compare means between frames for each of the two risk conditions. 

We will additionally conduct two OLS regressions, one for each risk condition, where we separately control for further variables (list below) to test the robustness of the results. 

DV: Likelihood to go to the party IV: frame, further control variables
 
Finally, we test the interaction between frame and risk condition with an OLS regression

DV: Likelihood to go to the party IV: frame, risk conditions, Interaction, further control variables
 
Control variables:
Demographics (Gender, Age)
Employment status
State of residence
Political orientation
General Risk seeking behavior
General willingness to give
Normlessness scale
Perceived risk questions with regards to COVID-19 (contracting, contracting serious illness, infecting others, infecting others and them contracting serious cases, relative risk compared to others to contract the disease
Known and serious cases of contracting among family and friends
Knowledge about Covid-19

outliers.value:
We exclude participants that do not complete the survey.

Additionally, we include an attention check in which participants are asked to give a specific answer. We exclude all participants that do not pass this attention check.

dependent.value: The dependent variable is the stated likelihood of going to a dinner party on a scale from 0 to 100 % (where 0 means not going for sure and 100 means going for sure)

conditions.value: Participants will be randomly assigned to one of 4 conditions. We vary the frame (avoid vs. adapt) and whether there is risk for becoming infected or risk for others to become infected (own risk, other risk)

hypothesis.value:
We test whether different framing of "Social Distancing" influences stated compliance with social distancing.

Hypothesis 1: When there is only low personal risk of being infected but risk that others become infected, framing social distancing as avoidance leads to less compliance compared to framing social distance as an approach.

Hypothesis 2: When there is low risk of infecting others and thus there is only a personal risk of becoming infected, framing social distancing as avoidance increases compliance compared to framing social distance as an approach.

registration_responses.conditions: Participants will be randomly assigned to one of four conditions in a 2 (Mindset: growth vs. fixed)  2 (Interest: high vs. low) in a factorial between-subjects design. Participants will read a fake scientific article that teaches readers that human characteristics are either fixed (or malleable). All participants complete the “saying is believing” procedure (Molden, Plaks, & Dweck, 2006). Participants then start an ostensibly unrelated study that in truth measures key DVs (evaluate information about a consumer product and capture CSD, interest, and other measured variables; see exploratory analyses).
registration_responses.hypothesis:
RQ: Does a growth (vs. fixed) mindset lead to greater consumer self-development? 

H1: Growth (vs. fixed) mindset consumers will perceive greater self-development when interest in hedonic learning is high compared to low.

attributes.title: Social Cost and Political Gain: The Effect of Mislabeling COVID-19 as "Chinese Virus"

data.value: No, no data have been collected for this study yet.

name.value:
Social Cost and Political Gain: The Effect of Mislabeling COVID-19 as "Chinese Virus"
We examine whether mislabeling COVID-19 as "Chinese Virus" leads to 1) more social stigmatization; 2) less social pressure of stigmatization; 3) less blame toward the federal government.

other.value:
A.	Subgroup analysis
To test H3, subgroup analysis will be conducted based on respondents’ reported partisanship. 
B.	Covariate analysis
1.	[Blame] explain correlations between control variables and blame in the “blame model”. 
2.	[Direct] explain correlations between control variables and driect “Agree” in the “direct model”. 
3.	We will compare results for who passes or failed the manipulation check question. 
C.	Re-weighted analysis
We will weight our data with iterative proportional fitting technique (raking) to match the US population. We will compare results for the original data and the weighted data.

sample.value: We will stop data collection once 1,200 subjects (approximately 300 per cell) have submitted a response on MTurk. Deviations from this goal are entirely due to MTurk software and outside of our control.

analyses.value:
Our analysis separate in three parts: blame, social stigmatization, and social desirability effect. 
	Blame
	The Average Treatment effect (ATE) will be visualized by a difference-in-means graphic.
	State fixed effect linear model with control covariates and clustered standard errors at the State level (“blame model”). 
	Stigmatization (answering “Agree” in the sensitive statement)
	[Direct Question] We use difference-in-means to examine the Chinese Virus treatment effect on the direct question. We will also report the percentage of answering “Agree” in the direct question. Finally, we will report a logit regression model with covariates (“direct model”). 
	[List item count] We will report ATE with difference-in-means between the 4-item list and 3-item list in both control and Chinese Virus treatment groups. 
	Social desirability effect (Coffman et al. 2017)
We subgroup our sample by control and Chinese Virus treatment groups. The following analysis will be done in both groups. We will compare results for both groups. 
	[Change in sensitive “Agree”] We observe direct question answer as d_i (0,1), and 3-item count answer as c_i (between 0 to 3). We measure the sum of both questions as y_i^D=d_i+c_i. We measure the 4-item count answer with one sensitive statement as y_i^S (between 0 to 4). Ideally, if there is no social desirability effect, y_i^D=y_i^S. So, we define the change in sensitive “Agree” as μ=y_i^S-y_i^D. To have a more precise analysis, we put our estimators into a regession to control geogrphical effects. The model is: 
y_i=〖βX〗_i+μS_i,{█(y_i=y_i^D  when S_i=0@y_i=y_i^S  when S_i=1)┤
Where, S_i (0,1) is the item-count list treatment and  X_i is a matrix of control covariates. We use State fixed-effect to control heterogenous COVID-19 confirmed cases by different states, and we also cluster standard errors at the State level. 
	[True fraction of sensitive “Agree”] =d ̅+μ
	[Percentage increase in sensitive “Agree”] =μ⁄d ̅ 

See the Chinese Virus Preregistration.pdf (https://osf.io/pv7zw/) for details.

outliers.value: An outlier is defined as being any point of data that lies over 1.5 IQRs below the first quartile (Q1) or above the third quartile (Q3)in the data set. We will compare and report the analytical results with and without outliers.

dependent.value:
a.	Social stigmatization. This construct is measured by asking whether or not the respondent agree with the statement, “Chinese immigrants damage the public health in the U.S.” It is a dichotomous variable (1=Agree, 0=Disagree). To filter the socially desirable responses, the statement is embedded in a list experiment. In the treatment group of the list experiment, we ask how many of the 4 listed statements (above statement included) do people agree with. In the control group of the list experiment, we ask how many of the 3 listed statements (above statement not included) do people agree with. The true support of the statement is the difference between the number of agreed statements in the treatment group and that in the control group.
b.	Social desirability bias. Social desirability bias will be detected through the analysis of the list experiment. See the Analyses Section for details. 
c.	Blame. This construct is measured by asking “overall, to what extent do you believe the federal government is deserving for blame for the current COVID-19/Chinese Virus outbreak?”. Responses are to be recorded on a 0-100 scale (0=Not at all to blame, 100=Completely to blame).

conditions.value: Participants will be randomly assigned to one of four conditions. There will be two experimental conditions for hypothesis testing. The intervention is to be delivered in terms of a vignette, which narrates the current situation of COVID-19 in the U.S. While keeping everything consistent, the vignette in the control group label the virus as COVID-19, and the virus name in the treatment group is manipulated as “Chinese Virus”. To measure social stigmatization, we will apply list experiment technique which further includes two conditions in each experimental condition. The control list experimental condition includes three controversial statements, while the treatment list experimental condition includes three same controversial statements plus one sensitive statement regarding social stigmatization.

hypothesis.value:
Research Questions:
1)	Does mislabeling COVID-19 as “Chinese Virus” lead to social stigmatization against Chinese immigrants in the U.S.?
2)	Does mislabeling COVID-19 as “Chinese Virus” reduce the blameworthiness of the federal government in response to the pandemic?
We raise four hypotheses to be tested in this study:
H1a: The label “Chinese Virus” will lead to social stigmatization against Chinese immigrants in the U.S.
H1b: The label “Chinese Virus” justifies stigmatization and therefore will lead to less social desirability bias in answering the question regarding stigmatization.
H2: The label “Chinese Virus” will lead to less blame against the federal government in handling the pandemic.
H3: The effect of “Chinese Virus” is divided based on people’s partisanship.

attributes.title: Partisan norm and perception of COVID-19
attributes.description: Partisans’ attitude toward Coronavirus depends on the norm from their political in-group more than out-group.

data.value: No, no data have been collected for this study yet.

analyses.value: Two regression analyses will be conducted for each dependent variable. The condition variable, participants’ party identity and a term for the interaction of the two will be entered in the models.

dependent.value:
To what extend do YOU PERSONALLY think that the COVID-19 pandemic is a real threat or blown out of proportion?

To what degree would you say that you are adhering to the CDC's advice for "social distance" (i.e., avoiding all non-essential in-person contact)?

conditions.value:
For this study, there are 2 conditions. All participants will be given one of the two following versions of news excerpt 
Version 1
"In early March, when the number of American coronavirus cases was still low and the president himself sounded unalarmed, many Americans generally told pollsters they were unworried, too. As the coronavirus toll has risen, concerns about the virus are now rising. One notable change from a recent poll is the responses from Democrats. Between Feb 26th and March 16th, Democrats who are “Not concerned at all” about a coronavirus outbreak in their local area has dropped by half. In contrast, Democrats who are “extremely concerned” about a coronavirus outbreak more than doubled. This trend is uniformly observed across different states, suggesting a consistently growing concerns from Democrat citizens in the United States."
Source: CIVIQS
Retrieved from: civiqs.com/results/coronavirus_concern?annotations=true&uncertainty=true&zoomIn=true

Version 2

q2.value:
1. Individuals scoring higher on loneliness will use their smartphones differently. Lonely individuals will exhibit a higher frequency of checking and will make more use of non-social phone functions, such that there will be positive correlations between these behaviours and self-report loneliness. Total time of smartphone usage will not be significantly correlated with self-report loneliness.

2. Self-report loneliness scores will be positively correlated with neuroticism, harmavoidance, social recognition, and succorance, and will be negatively correlated with affiliation.

3. There will be a positive correlation between communication apprehension scores and loneliness ratings, as well as between communication apprehension with duration and frequency of smartphone use.

4. There will be a negative correlation between loneliness and emotional support.

q3.value: Observational Study - Data is collected from study subjects that are not randomly assigned to a treatment. This includes surveys, “natural experiments,” and regression discontinuity designs.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: This study is a correlational design, using a variety of measures assessed using an online survey form.

q8.value: Registration prior to accessing the data

q9.value: At the time of registration, the data has been partially collected. It has been monitored in order to ensure that the online study is functioning properly, by observing the time spent completing the survey, as well as scanning items to check if they are they are being completed. No calculations have occurred, and most variables require a total score in order to be properly interpreted.

question.value: This study intends to include 500 students in Western University recruited from the SONA participant pool. Participants are granted 0.5 course research credits for completing the survey. If we do not have enough participants, we will submit a request for a mass email through the Computer Accounts Office.

q11.value: The study aims to recruit 500 participants in this sample.

q12.value: The inclusion of a large sample size is to accommodate geographical and demographical limitations on this study and in anticipation of incomplete surveys and withdrawals from the study.

question.value:
UCLA Loneliness Scale (Version 3; Russell, 1996). The UCLA Loneliness Scale is one of the most widely used self-report measures of loneliness. It consists of 20 items on a 4-point Likert scale of “Often”, “Sometimes”, “Rarely”, “Never”, resulting in an overall aggregate score of loneliness. Vassar and Crosby (2008) have found generalized reliability estimates of .86 to .95 across 13 studies for the UCLA 3. The scale has also been shown to have good construct and convergent validity (Russell, 1996). 
Personality Assessment Inventory, Non-Support Scale (PAI Non-support; Morey, 1991). The PAI Non-Support is an 8-item subscale of the PAI which seeks to evaluate the amount of family and friend support that an individual perceives. This scale is included in this study as a method of corroborating participants’ assessment of their loneliness on the UCLA Loneliness Scale. Items are rated as “true” or “false”. 
Personal Report of Communication Apprehension scale (PRCA-24; McCroskey, 1982). The PRCA-24 is a 24-item self-report measure of anxiety in different types of communication. The scale is divided into four types of communicative situations including participating in group discussions, speaking in meetings, engaging in conversations, and giving a speech. Participants rate whether each statement applies to them on a 5-point scale from 1 “strongly disagree” to 5 “strongly agree”. Ratings can be aggregated into the four specific situations, or can be compiled as a total score. Internal consistency estimates (alphas) range from .93 to .95 (McCroskey, Beatty, Kearny, & Plax, 1985).
NEO-PI-R (Costa & McCrae, 1992). The NEO-PI-R is a self-report inventory of personality. The present study uses the items for the neuroticism subscale. These items are further divided into 6 facets of neuroticism: anxiety, angry hostility, depression, self-consciousness, impulsiveness, vulnerability. Items are statements that are evaluated on a 5-point scale of how much the statement applies to the rater from 1 “Strongly Agree” to 5 “Strongly Disagree”. Internal consistency reliability for the neuroticism scale is reported to be .90 (Costa & McCrae, 1992).
Personality Research Form (PRF; Jackson, 1989), select subscales. The Affiliation, Harmavoidance, Social Recognition, and Succorance facets of the PRF were selected for this study. Each contains sixteen statements which participants rate as “true” or “false”. From the PRF manual (Jackson, 1989), internal consistency reliabilities for the scales of interest are: .88 (Affiliation), .91 (Harmavoidance), .91 (Social Recognition), and .91 (Succorance).
Smartphone use. Smartphone use will be evaluated objectively using three different types of information taken from built-in apps on Apple iPhone devices and Huawei Android devices. These two types of device were chosen specifically because they collect weekly totals of the information, which will give a broader picture of typical use than a daily snapshot. Participants will be instructed on how to access the appropriate information. They will first enter their weekly screen time, which gives an idea of how much time is spent overall on their smartphone. Participants are also asked to enter the number of “pick ups” (iPhone) or “unlocks” (Huawei), which is an estimate of how frequently individuals are using and checking their smartphones.  The third type of information for participants to enter is the five most used apps, which will be coded into categories, based on the Apple App Store. In addition to the objective data, participants are also asked to rank order 15 possible smartphone uses in order of importance to them. 
Demographic information. Age and gender information will be collected, as well as living arrangements. Participants are asked to choose from options that best describe their living situation: “Alone”, “With roommates (shared common spaces)”, “With a spouse/long term partner”, “With parents/relatives/caregivers” or “Other (please specify)”.

Data will first be reviewed using descriptive statistics and an analysis of demographic information. A one-way ANOVA will be conducted to assess whether loneliness changes as a factor of living arrangements. Independent samples t-tests will be conducted to evaluate gender differences in loneliness and correlations will be conducted for age and loneliness. 
Correlation analysis will be used to address the first four hypotheses described above. For hypothesis 1, correlations between the UCLA Loneliness Scale ratings, and the smartphone use data will be assessed. The smartphone uses of interest are frequency (“pick ups”), duration (total screen time), and purpose (most used apps, coded), as well as importance (ranked smartphone uses). Hypothesis 2 will examine correlations between the UCLA Loneliness Scale ratings and scores on the NEO-PI-R neuroticism scale, as well as each of the four PRF scales. Hypothesis 3 correlations will be evaluated between scores on the UCLA Loneliness Scale and the PRCA-24. Lastly (hypothesis 4), correlations will be analysed between the UCLA Loneliness Scale and the PAI Non-support scale.

q22.value: An exploratory multiple regression analysis will be conducted to examine which of the predictors, age, gender, living arrangements, smartphone use (frequency, duration, purpose), NEO-PI-R scores, PRF Scale scores, PRCA-24 scores, and PAI non-support scores best predict total self-report UCLA Loneliness Scale scores.

From the PRF manual (Jackson, 1989), internal consistency reliabilities for the scales of interest are: .88 (Affiliation), .91 (Harmavoidance), .91 (Social Recognition), and .91 (Succorance).
Smartphone use. Smartphone use will be evaluated objectively using three different types of information taken from built-in apps on Apple iPhone devices and Huawei Android devices. These two types of device were chosen specifically because they collect weekly totals of the information, which will give a broader picture of typical use than a daily snapshot. Participants will be instructed on how to access the appropriate information. They will first enter their weekly screen time, which gives an idea of how much time is spent overall on their smartphone. Participants are also asked to enter the number of “pick ups” (iPhone) or “unlocks” (Huawei), which is an estimate of how frequently individuals are using and checking their smartphones.  The third type of information for participants to enter is the five most used apps, which will be coded into categories, based on the Apple App Store. In addition to the objective data, participants are also asked to rank order 15 possible smartphone uses in order of importance to them. 
Demographic information. Age and gender information will be collected, as well as living arrangements. Participants are asked to choose from options that best describe their living situation: “Alone”, “With roommates (shared common spaces)”, “With a spouse/long term partner”, “With parents/relatives/caregivers” or “Other (please specify)”.
registration_responses.q17.question:
Data will first be reviewed using descriptive statistics and an analysis of demographic information. A one-way ANOVA will be conducted to assess whether loneliness changes as a factor of living arrangements. Independent samples t-tests will be conducted to evaluate gender differences in loneliness and correlations will be conducted for age and loneliness. 
Correlation analysis will be used to address the first four hypotheses described above. For hypothesis 1, correlations between the UCLA Loneliness Scale ratings, and the smartphone use data will be assessed. The smartphone uses of interest are frequency (“pick ups”), duration (total screen time), and purpose (most used apps, coded), as well as importance (ranked smartphone uses). Hypothesis 2 will examine correlations between the UCLA Loneliness Scale ratings and scores on the NEO-PI-R neuroticism scale, as well as each of the four PRF scales. Hypothesis 3 correlations will be evaluated between scores on the UCLA Loneliness Scale and the PRCA-24. Lastly (hypothesis 4), correlations will be analysed between the UCLA Loneliness Scale and the PAI Non-support scale.

attributes.title: COVID-19 Poll
attributes.description: The current project was designed to gather information for animal welfare organizations in light of the current outbreak of COVID-19. We asked members of these groups to submit survey ideas in order to determine what information would best help the wide range of organizations who make up our audience.

q2.value: We had no specific hypotheses for the research.

q3.value: Observational Study - Data is collected from study subjects that are not randomly assigned to a treatment. This includes surveys, “natural experiments,” and regression discontinuity designs.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

q8.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value: Participants will be 1,000 general population US citizens who are at least 18 years old and who agree to participate in a poll run by Ipsos Public Affairs on the behalf of Faunalytics. Ipsos recruits participants, administers the survey, and provides compensation. The survey is administered by Ipsos through an online knowledge panel.

q12.value: 1,000 participants is conventional for polls because it provides estimates of population parameters with an approximately 3% margin of error

question.value:
There were five questions in the survey:

1) Open-ended, asking about people’s understanding of the origins of the disease
2) True or false questions about facts relating to the disease
3) Agreement or disagreement with statements on topics such as linking the outbreak to animal agriculture and outcomes
4) Intentions to change diet or donation behavior
5) Ratings of a statement linking the outbreak to animal agriculture

See the attached file for the full survey.

We are interested in the proportion of respondents who endorsed each of the response options to each of our closed-ended questions. Therefore, we will primarily use descriptive statistics. Each of the closed-ended questions will also be broken down by available demographics, and any potential differences between these disaggregated groups will be determined by significance testing (conducted by Ipsos Public Affairs).

q19.value: We will use a conventional p < .05 criteria for determining significance.  Because this is exploratory work, we will not correct alpha levels.

q20.value: Ipsos are responsible for excluding any participants or data points from their analyses. For any correlations we conduct, outliers will be removed on an analysis-by-analysis basis using residuals.

q21.value: Data will be excluded casewise during analyses. Because of the method of data collection, we do not expect more than 5% missing data on any question, but we will follow the procedures outlined in Tabachnick & Fidell should this occur.

q22.value: In exploratory analyses, we may also consider whether there is a correlation between knowledge of certain facts about COVID, endorsement of other beliefs, or intended behaviors (e.g., items in questions 2, 3, and 4), and support for a link between the outbreak and animal agriculture (e.g., responses to question 5). We may also consider correlations or between any other combination of the included variables.
